# George Washington Carver National Monument

| area_acre = 240
| area_ref =
| authorized =
| visitation_num = 46,397
| visitation_year = 2016
| visitation_ref =
| governing_body = National Park Service

| refnum = 66000114
}}
}}
George Washington Carver National Monument is a unit of the National Park Service in Newton County, Missouri, United States. The national monument was founded on July 14, 1943, by Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who dedicated $30,000 to the monument. It was the first national monument dedicated to an African American and first to a non-president.
The site preserves the boyhood home of George Washington Carver, as well as the 1881 Moses Carver house and the Carver cemetery. His boyhood home consists of rolling hills, woodlands, and prairies. The  park has a -mile (1.2 km) nature trail, film, museum, and an interactive exhibit area for students.
The park is two miles west of Diamond along Missouri Route V and approximately ten miles southeast of Joplin.
It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1966.
]]
